I have about 6kg of mercury that was given to me years ago by a company that serviced sphygmomanometers. It was contaminated with glass and oil, and I cleaned it up for my uses.

I store the mercury in a reagent jar with a greased ground glass stopper. No water is held over the mercury.

This bottle is in turn stored inside a 5 gallon pail, with foam holding the glass bottle securely within the secondary container. The pail has a tight fitting lid and is marked with a poison warning along with a description of the contents.

Since I live in an earthquake zone, I store this pail in the most secure part of my house, which just happens to be the furnace room. In the winter, the room gets to maybe 30C, so it isn't that hot. The vapor is contained by my double storage system anyhow, and the mercury is very infrequently accessed.

Other than storing this mercury in a bank vault, I think I've done everything I can to ensure that it never contaminates the environment.
